millsfield:images_texts:
October
1933
PERSONAL
Mr. H. M.
Bixby,
Pacific American Airways Company,
Room 411,
3 Canton Road,
Shanghai, China.
Dear Harold:
As you know, during the last month we have had
the
pleasure of seeing a number of people who have been in contact with
you in China and who have been able to report to us on the situation
over there and on your activities.
In short, we have been able to
get a very good "check up" on you,
and I may say frankly that we
feel we have all the "lowdown"
date.
I think it only fair,
therefore,
to let
you know
that these reports coming from people who have been in close con-
tact with you recently, have been overwhelmingly favorable.
To
put it briefly, we have
been given very definitely and firmly to
understand that if we had searched the world over for just the
right person to handle the difficult and complicated job which was
laid on your shoulders, it would have been impossible to find anybody
either better suited for it by general ability and temperament, or
who could have handled the situation as it developed anywhere near as
well as you have.
We have been informed, and have every reason to
believe,
that your standing with our Chinese associates and with
Government officials is not only of the best, but it is marked by
sentiments which come very close to real affection for you on their
part.
A11
this has been duly noted, not only by your faithful
friend the undersigned, but also, much more important, by Mr. J. T.
Trippe, who has
received this startling news at first hand direct
from the people
concerned, and who, I have every reason to believe,
is satisfied of
its accuracy.
He has had some very sound advice
on the Chinese
situation from these parties, and
certain important
facts which you had
made very plain in your reports, and which I had
not failed to call to his attention, have been even further impressed
upon him.
above, for your
personal information, may serve as
some slight encouragement in the midst of your trials.
Anyway I hope
you will appreciate
that we are all pulling for you and, far from being
disposed to
be
critical, are most sympathetic with your difficulties
and
well
satisfied
with
what you have succeeded in accomplishing so far.
With kindest regards.
Sincerely yours,
Sumogan
SWM: FP 3
properties.sfomuseum:description: Typewritten letter from S. [Stokely] W. Morgan to Harold M. Bixby, dated October 3, 1933; includes description of positive attitude of Pan American Airways and J.T. [Juan] Trippe toward Mr. Bixby.
properties.wof:name: correspondence: S.W. Morgan to Harold M. Bixby
